revision.text:
{|{{Infobox aircraft begin |name = JN "Jenny" |image = Flying jenny cropped.jpg |caption =Curtiss JN-4 Jenny, 1918 }}{{Infobox aircraft type |type = Trainer |manufacturer = [[Curtiss Aeroplane and Motor Company|Curtiss]] |designer = Benjamin D. Thomas |first flight = |introduced = 1915 |retired = |produced = |number built = 6,813 |unit cost = $5,465 |primary user = [[U.S. Army Air Service]] |more users = [[Royal Flying Corps]] |developed from = |variants with their own articles = [[Curtiss N-9]]
[[Curtiss JN-6H]] }} |} The '''Curtiss JN-4 "Jenny"''' was one of a series of "JN" [[biplane]]s built by the Curtiss Aeroplane Company of [[Hammondsport, New York]], later the [[Curtiss Aeroplane and Motor Company]]. Although the Curtiss JN series was originally produced as a training aircraft for the U.S. Army, the "Jenny" (the common nickname derived from "JN-4", with an open-topped four appearing as a ''Y'') continued after World War I as a civil aircraft, as it became the "backbone of American post[[World War I|war]] [civil] aviation."Auliard 2009, p. 44. Thousands of surplus Jennys were sold at bargain prices to private owners in the years after the war and became central to the [[barnstorming]] era that helped awaken America to civil aviation through much of the 1920s.Rumerman, Judy. "The Curtiss JN-4 "Jenny". ''U.S. Centennial of Flight Commission'', 2003. ==Design and development== Curtiss combined the best features of the [[Curtiss Model J|model J]] and model N [[Training aircraft|trainers]], built for the [[United States Army|Army]] and [[United States Navy|Navy]], and began producing the JN or "Jenny" series of aircraft in 1915.Roseberry 1972, p. 477. Curtiss built only a limited number of the JN-1 and JN-2 [[biplane]]s. The design was commissioned by [[Glenn Curtiss]] from Englishman Benjamin Douglas Thomas, formerly of the [[Sopwith Aviation Company]].Angelucci 1973, p. 41. The JN-2 was an equal-span biplane with [[aileron]]s controlled by a shoulder yoke in the aft [[cockpit]].Bowers 1966, p. 7. It was deficient in performance, particularly climbing, because of excessive weight. The improved JN-3 incorporated unequal spans with ailerons only on the upper wings, controlled by a [[Joystick|wheel]]. In addition, a foot bar was added to control the [[rudder]].Donald 1997, pp. 279–280. [[File:Curtiss JN-3.jpg|thumb|left|Curtiss JN-3, the progenitor of the JN-4, deployed to Mexico, around 1916]] The [[1st Reconnaissance Squadron|1st Aero Squadron]] of the [[Aviation Section, U.S. Signal Corps]] received eight JN-2s at San Diego in July 1915. The squadron was transferred to [[Fort Sill]], [[Oklahoma]], in August to work with the Field Artillery School, during which one JN-2 crashed, resulting in a fatality.Larson 2004, pp. 19–20. The pilots of the squadron met with its commander, Capt. [[Benjamin Foulois]], to advise that the JN-2 was unsafe because of low power, shoddy construction, lack of stability, and overly sensitive rudder. Foulois and his executive officer Capt. [[Thomas D. Milling]] disagreed, and flights continued until a second JN-2 crashed in early September, resulting in the grounding of the six remaining JN-2s until mid-October. When two new JN-3s were delivered, the grounded aircraft were then upgraded in accordance with the new design. In March 1916, these eight JN-3s were deployed to Mexico for [[Reconnaissance|aerial observation]] during the [[Pancho Villa Expedition]] of 1916–1917.House 2003 p. 168. After the successful deployment of the JN-3, Curtiss produced a development, known as the JN-4, with orders from both the US Army and an order in December 1916 from the [[Royal Flying Corps]] for a training aircraft to be based in Canada.{{#tag:ref|Both the US Army version and the Canadian derivative for the Royal Flying Corps were known as JN-4s. To differentiate between the types, unofficially, the RFC designation was the JN-4 (Canadian).|group=N}} The Canadian version was the JN-4 (Canadian), also known as the "[[Canuck]]", had some minor differences from the US version, including a lighter airframe, ailerons on both wings, a bigger and more rounded rudder, and differently shaped wings, stabilizer, and elevators.Molson and Taylor 1982, p. 219. ==Operational history== [[File:Curtiss JN-4s.jpg|thumb|Curtiss JN-4Ds at Camp Taliaferro, Texas, ''circa'' 1918]] The Curtiss JN-4 is possibly [[North America]]'s most famous [[World War I]] aircraft. It was widely used during World War I to train beginning pilots, with an estimated 95% of all trainees having flown a JN-4. The U.S. version was called "Jenny", a derivation from its official designation. It was a twin-seat (student in front of instructor) dual-control biplane. Its [[tractor configuration|tractor]] propeller and maneuverability made it ideal for initial pilot training with a {{convert|90|hp|kW|lk=in|abbr=on}} [[Curtiss OX-5]] [[V8 engine]] giving a top speed of {{convert|75|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} and a service [[Ceiling (aeronautics)|ceiling]] of {{convert|6500|ft|m|abbr=on}}."The Engine that Saved Aviation: OX-5." '' Air Classics,'' Issue 3, Fall 1965, p. 30. The British used the JN-4 (Canadian), along with the [[Avro 504]], for their primary World War I trainer using the [[Canadian Aeroplanes Ltd.]] indigenous variant.Molson and Taylor 1982, p. 225. Many Royal Flying Corps pilots earned their wings on the JN-4, both in [[Ontario]] and later in winter facilities at [[Camp Taliaferro]], Texas.Chajkowsky 1979, p. 55. [[File:JN-4 ambulance.jpg|thumb|Converted JN-4 ambulance, operated by the [[Camp Taliaferro]] medical teams, around 1918]] Although ostensibly a training aircraft, the Jenny was extensively modified while in service to undertake additional roles. Due to its robust but easily adapted structure able to be modified with ski undercarriage, the Canadian Jenny was flown year-round, even in inclement weather.[http://www.abheritage.ca/aviation/history/ww1_toronto.html "Royal Flying Corps Starts Training in Toronto."] ''abheritage.ca.'' Retrieved: 10 September 2011. The removable turtle-deck behind the cockpits allowed for conversion to stretcher or additional supplies and equipment storage, with the modified JN-4s becoming the first aerial ambulances, carrying out this role both during wartime and in later years.Hurd and Jernigan 2002, p. 7. Most of the 6,813 Jennys built were unarmed, although some had [[machine gun]]s and [[bomb]] racks for advanced training. With deployment limited to North American bases, none saw combat service in World War I. The Curtiss factory in Buffalo, New York, was the largest such facility in the world, but due to production demands, from November 1917 to January 1919, six different manufacturers were involved in production of the definitive JN-4D.Winchester 2004, p. 88. Production from spare or reconditioned parts continued sporadically until 1927, although most of the final orders were destined for the civil market in Canada and the United States.Winchester 2004, p. 89. Like the re-engined 'JN-4H' version of the most-produced JN-4 subtype, the final production version of the aircraft was the [[Curtiss JN-6H|JN-6]], powered by a [[Wright Aeronautical]] license-built, 150-hp (112-kW) [[Hispano-Suiza 8]] V-8, first ordered in 1918 for the US Navy. A [[floatplane]] version was built for the Navy which was so modified, it was essentially a different airframe. This was designated the [[Curtiss N-9|N-9]]. In [[U.S. Army Air Service]] usage, the JN-4s and JN-6s were configured to the JNS ("S" for "standardized") model. The Jenny remained in service with the US Army until 1927. [[File:JN-4 and wingwalker.jpg|thumb|One of the many daredevil stunts performed by JN-4 pilots was to work with a "wingwalker".]] After World War I, thousands were sold on the civilian market, including one to [[Charles Lindbergh]] in May 1923, in which he then soloed.Lindbergh 1927, pp. 39–43.[http://www.charleslindbergh.com/plane/firstplane.asp "Charles Lindbergh's First Solo Flight & First Plane."] ''Charles Lindbergh official site.'' Surplus US Army aircraft were sold, some still in their unopened packing crates, for as little as $50, essentially "flooding" the market.{{#tag:ref|Surplus JN-4s typically fetched between $200 and $500, depending on condition.|group=N}} With private and commercial flying in North America unhampered by regulations concerning their use, pilots found the Jenny's slow speed and stability made it ideal for stunt flying and [[Aerobatics|aerobatic]] displays in the barnstorming era between the world wars, with the nearly identical [[Standard J|Standard J-1]] aircraft often used alongside it. {{#tag:ref|The front cockpit that was normally for the student in military training was usually used for passengers in postwar joy rides, so the pilot could keep an eye on his paying customer/s.|group=N}} Some were still flying into the 1930s.{{#tag:ref|The JN-4 Canuck was often chosen for barnstorming as the lighter, more responsive, and more economical variant was also in large supply.|group=N}} JN-4 airframes were used to produce early [[Weaver Aircraft Company]] / [[Advance Aircraft Company]] / [[Waco Aircraft Company|Waco]] aircraft, such as the [[Waco 6]]. ===Notable firsts=== Between 1917 and 1919, the JN-4 type accounted for several significant aviation "firsts" while in service with the US Army Signal Corps Aviation Section and the [[United States Marine Corps]] (USMC) including flying the [[Airmails of the United States#U.S. Government flown Air Mail|first U.S. Air Mail]] in May 1918. In a series of tests conducted at the U.S. Army's [[Langley Field]] in Hampton, Virginia, in July and August 1917, the world's first "plane-to-plane" and "ground-to-plane, and vice versa" communications by radiotelephony (as opposed to radiotelegraphy which had been developed earlier) were made to and from modified US Army JN-4s{{#tag:ref|Quote: "A JN-4-d plane was used; speed was successful, transmitting about 3 miles from plane to plane and was also received from ground to plane, and vice versa." "Report of the Chief Signal Officer to the Secretary of War, October 15, 1919". ''Annual Report,'' War Department, 1919, pp. 262–263.|group=N}} by [[Western Electric Company]] ([[Bell Labs]]) design engineers Lewis M. Clement and Raymond Heising, the developers of the experimental wind generator-powered airborne wireless voice transmitter and receiver equipment."Handwritten letter, dated August 18, 1917, from Western Electric Co (Bell Labs) design engineer Lewis M. Clement to Vesta L. Clement, his wife, with a detailed first-person account of the first successful test of 'plane-to-plane' and 'plane-to-ground' radiotelephony from JN-4-d airplanes in flight conducted that day at Langley Field, VA." ''The Cooper Collection of U.S. Aviation History'' (Private collection: original letter location), Ardmore, Pennsylvania.[http://cprr.org/Museum/Radio.html "Lewis Mason Clement: Pioneer of Radio."] ''CPRR.org,'' September 2010. Retrieved: 5 September 2011. In early 1919, a United States Marine Corps (USMC) JN-4 was also credited with what is believed to be the first successful "[[dive bombing]]" attack during the [[United States occupation of Haiti]]. USMC pilot Lt Lawson H. Sanderson mounted a carbine barrel in front of the windshield of his JN-4 (previously, an unarmed trainer that had a machine gun mounted in the rear cockpit) as an improvised bomb sight that was lined up with the long axis of his aircraft, loaded a bomb in a canvas mail bag that was attached to the JN-4's belly, and launched a single-handed raid at treetop level, in support of a USMC unit that had been trapped by Haitian Cacos rebels.[http://www.ausflying.com.au/news/debunking-dive-bomber-myths "Debunking dive bomber myths."] ''Flightpath'', Volume 21, Number 4, 17 April 2010. Although the JN-4 almost disintegrated in the pullout, the attack was effective and led to Sanderson in 1920 developing further dive-bombing techniques to provide Marine pilots with close aerial support to infantry comrades.Nowarra 1982, p. 8. == Variants == [[File:Curtiss JN-4 CAN.jpg|thumb|A JN-4 C227 "Canuck" (USAAS #39158) operated by the US Air Army Air Service in 1918, is now restored and on display at the Canada Aviation and Space Museum.]] Although the first series of JN-4s were virtually identical to the JN-3, the JN-4 series was based on production orders from 1915–1919.Auliard 2009, pp. 46–47. *'''JN-4A''' — production version of the JN-4, 781 built *'''JN-4B''' — This version was powered by an OX-2 piston engine; 76 were built for the U.S. Army, and nine for the U.S. Navy. *'''JN-4C''' — experimental version, only two were built *'''JN-4 (Canadian) [[Canadian English#Canadian colloquialisms|Canuck]]''' — Canadian-built version, 1,260 built by Canadian Aeroplanes Ltd. for the RFC in Canada/RAF in Canada and USAAC: Independently derived from the JN-3, it had a lighter airframe, ailerons on both wings, a bigger and more rounded rudder, and differently shaped wings, stabilizer, and elevators. Its use by the USAAC was curtailed as the lighter structure was claimed to cause more accidents than the US-built aircraft, although no air fatalities were attributed to the structural integrity of the type.Molson and Taylor 1982, pp. 225–226. *'''JN-4D''' — improved version, adopting the control stick from the JN-4 (Canadian) 2,812 built **'''JN-4D-2''' — One prototype only, the engine mount was revised to eliminate the down thrust position.Auliard 2009, p. 46. *'''JN-4H''' — two-seat advanced trainer biplane with ailerons on both wings, 929 built for the U.S. Army, notable for introducing the use of the [[Wright Aeronautical]] license-built [[Hispano-Suiza 8]] V-8 engine for greater power and reliability **'''JN-4HT''' — two-seat, dual-control trainer version **'''JN-4HB''' — bombing trainer version **'''JN-4HG''' — gunnery trainer version **'''JN-4HM''' — communications conversion of JN-4HT, powered by Wright-Hisso E 150-hp (112-kW), six converted, used to fly the first US Air Mail (May–August, 1918) *'''JN-5H''' — advanced trainer biplane, only one built *'''JN-6''' — improved version of JN-5 trainer biplane series, notably used four ailerons, 1,035 built for the US Army and five for the U.S. Navy *'''JN-6H''' — improved version of the JN-6 **'''JN-6BH''' — bomber trainer version **'''JN-6HG-1''' — two-seat, dual-control trainer version, 560 built from JN-6 production, 34 for US Navy **'''JN-6HG-2''' — single-control gunnery trainer. 90 delivered **'''JN-6HO''' — single-control observer trainer version, 106 deliveredAuliard 2009, p. 47. **'''JN-6HP''' — single-control pursuit fighter trainer version *'''JNS''' ("standardized")  — During the postwar years of the early 1920s, between 200 and 300 U.S. Army aircraft were upgraded to a common standard of equipment and modernized. ==="Specials"=== [[File:Curtiss Twin JN.jpg|thumb|The most radical development of the Curtiss JN-4 was the Twin JN (or "Twin Jenny") in limited production and service with the US military.]] *'''Allison Monoplane''' — conversion of JN-4 (Can) G-CAJL by the Allison Company, Kansas, that mounted a parasol wing in place of the biplane configuration, only one conversion madeMolson 1964, p. 62. *'''Curtiss Special''' (1918) — a smaller, custom-built, single-seat variant for [[Katherine Stinson]], powered by a 100-;hp (74.5-kW) OXX-6 {{#tag:ref|Stinson's aircraft built to her specifications was used for fundraising tours for the [[American Red Cross]]. During exhibition flights in Canada, she set a [[Canadians|Canadian]] distance and endurance record, and made the second air mail flight in Canada between Calgary and Edmonton, Alberta. A replica is at the [[Alberta Aviation Museum]].Chalmers, John. [http://www.vintagewings.ca/VintageNews/Stories/tabid/116/articleType/ArticleView/articleId/86/language/en-CA/Youve-Got-Mail-an-Alabaman-Aviatrix-in-Alberta.aspx "You've Got Mail... an Alabaman Aviatrix in Alberta: Katherine Stinson and the Curtiss Special."] ''Vintage News,'' Retrieved: 10 September 2011.|group=N}} *'''Ericson Special Three''' — Some reconditioned aircraft built by Canadian Aeroplanes Ltd. were fitted with a third cockpit. *'''Hennessey Monoplane''' — [http://www.flickr.com/photos/sdasmarchives/4590495214/sizes/o/in/photostream/ "Hennessey Monoplane."] ''San Diego Air and Space Museum Archives.'' Retrieved: 6 September 2011. a 1926 monoplane conversion by James R. Hennessey, three-place transport, 90-hp Curtiss OX-5, span: 36 ft (11 m) length: 25 ft (7.6 m)[http://aerofiles.com/_h.html "Hennessey."] ''Aerofiles.'' Retrieved: 6 September 2011.{{Citation needed|date=September 2011}} *'''Severski''' 1926 biplane  — a JN-4 modified with a roller/ski undercarriage, one experimental aircraft converted by the [[Republic Aviation|Seversky]] company[http://aerofiles.com/_sa.html "Severski."] ''Aerofiles.'' Retrieved: 10 September 2011.{{#tag:ref|The name "Severski" was a play on designer [[Alexander P. de Seversky]]'s name, emphasizing the use of skis.|group=N}} *'''Sperry Monoplane''' — conversion offered by the Sperry Company that mounted a parasol wing in place of the biplane configuration[http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1921/1921%20-%200509.html "Sperry 'Commercial' Wing."] ''Flight,'' 23 July 1921. *'''Twin JN''' — An enlarged twin-engined version of the JN-4, they were powered by two OXX-2 piston engines, built in 1916 as the JN-5 for an observation role; among the many other modifications was an enlarged wingspan and new rudder adapted from the Curtiss Model R-4. Two of the series saw action with the US Army on the Mexican border in 1916–1917. A total of eight Twin JNs were built, with two in US Navy service. ==Operators== [[File:KMT雙翼機.JPG|thumbnail|JN-4 used by the [[Republic of China]]]] ===Military operators=== ;{{ARG}} *[[Argentine Naval Aviation]] ;{{AUS}} *[[Australian Flying Corps]] **[[No. 3 Squadron RAAF|No. 3 Squadron AFC]] - Used for training. **[[Central Flying School RAAF|Central Flying School AFC]] at [[Point Cook, Victoria]]. [[File:Curtiss JN-4 (Can) dwg.jpg|thumb|right|Drawing of the Curtiss JN-4 (Can) or "Canuck"]];{{BRA}} *[[Brazilian Naval Aviation]] (JN-4D variant) ;{{flag|Canada|1921}} *[[Royal Flying Corps Canada]] (primarily JN-4 (Can) variant) *[[Royal Canadian Air Force]] ;{{CUB}} *[[Cuban Air Force]] ;{{UK}} * [[Royal Flying Corps]] ** [[No. 24 Squadron RAF|No. 24 Squadron RFC]] ** [[No. 25 Squadron RAF|No. 25 Squadron RFC]] *[[Royal Naval Air Service]] ;{{USA}} *[[Aviation Section, U.S. Signal Corps|United States Army Signal Corps Aviation Section]] (1915) *[[Aviation Section, U.S. Signal Corps|United States Army Signal Corps Aeronautical Division]] (1915–1918) *[[United States Army Air Service]] (1918 et seq.) *[[United States Marine Corps]] *[[United States Navy]] ;{{ROC}} *[[National Revolutionary Army]] in the [[Northern Expedition]]. ===Civil operators=== ;{{flag|Canada|1921}} *Elliot Air Service, [[Red Lake, Ontario]]Molson 1974, p. 4. ==Survivors== [[File:Frontiers of Flight Museum December 2015 106 (Curtiss JN-4D "Jenny").jpg|thumb|The JN-4D on display at the [[Frontiers of Flight Museum]]]] [[File:CurtisJenny.jpg|thumb|The JN-4D on display at the National Museum of the United States Air Force]] [[File:Curtiss JN-4D at San Diego museum.jpg|thumb|upright|Curtiss JN-4D at the [[San Diego Air and Space Museum]] is being restored (to reskin the wings) prior to future display.[http://www.sandiegoairandspace.org/collections/ "Aircraft Collections."] ''San Diego Air and Space Museum.'' Retrieved: 6 September 2011.{{dead link|date=October 2016}}]] [[File:16 19 021 JN4.jpg|thumb|1917 JN-4 on display at the [[Museum of Aviation (Warner Robins)|Museum of Aviation]], [[Robins AFB]]]] About 50 Jennys survive in museums and with private owners.{{citation needed|date=September 2016}} *1282 – JN-4D airworthy at the [[Western Antique Aeroplane & Automobile Museum]] in [[Hood River, Oregon]].{{cite web|title=Curtiss JN-4D "Jenny"|url=http://www.waaamuseum.org/collections/airplanes/174-Curtiss-JN-4D-%22Jenny%22|website=Western Antique Aeroplane and Automobile Museum|publisher=WAAAM|accessdate=29 September 2016}}{{cite web|title=Curtiss JN-4D "Jenny" - WAAAM's Crown Jewel|url=http://www.waaamuseum.org/collections/our-stories/226-curtiss-jn-4d-jenny-waaam-s-crown-jewel|website=Western Antique Aeroplane and Automobile Museum|publisher=WAAAM|accessdate=30 September 2016}}{{cite web|title=Airframe Dossier - Curtiss JN-4D Jenny, s/n 1282 USAAS, c/r N1282|url=http://aerialvisuals.ca/AirframeDossier.php?Serial=20582|website=Aerial Visuals|publisher=AerialVisuals.ca|accessdate=30 September 2016}}{{cite web|title=FAA REGISTRY [N1282]|url=http://registry.faa.gov/aircraftinquiry/NNum_Results.aspx?NNumbertxt=N1282|website=Federal Aviation Administration|publisher=U.S. Department of Transportation|accessdate=30 September 2016}} *2805 – JN-4D on static display at the [[National Museum of the United States Air Force]] in [[Dayton, Ohio]]. It was obtained from Robert Pfiel of [[Taylor, Texas]] in 1956. The aircraft is displayed in the Museum's Early Years gallery.{{cite web|title=Curtiss JN-4D Jenny|url=http://www.nationalmuseum.af.mil/Visit/MuseumExhibits/FactSheets/Display/tabid/509/Article/197406/curtiss-jn-4d-jenny.aspx|website=National Museum of the US Air Force|accessdate=29 September 2016}}{{cite web|title=AIRCRAFT, DRONES AND MISSILES AT THE NATIONAL MUSEUM OF THE U.S. AIR FORCE|url=http://www.nationalmuseum.af.mil/Portals/7/documents/other/nmusaf_alpha_aircraft_list.pdf|accessdate=30 September 2016|date=June 2016}} *5368 – JN-4D on static display at the [[Museum of Science and Industry (Chicago)|Museum of Science and Industry]] in [[Chicago, Illinois]]. It is displayed upside down next to a wraparound balcony, and details of the cockpit can readily be seen. This airframe was built in 1917.{{cite web|title=1917 Curtiss JN-4D|url=http://www.msichicago.org/explore/whats-here/exhibits/transportation-gallery/the-exhibit/smaller-aircraft/curtiss-jn-4d|website=Museum of Science and Industry|publisher=Museum of Science and Industry, Chicago|accessdate=29 September 2016}} It was cleaned and reskinned by Century Aviation in 2006.{{cite web|title=1917 Curtiss JN-4D 'Jenny'|url=http://century-aviation.com/essential_grid/1917-curtiss-jn-4d-jenny|website=Century Aviation|publisher=Century Aviation|accessdate=30 September 2016}} *8644 – Airworthy at the [[Sonoma Valley Airport]] in [[Sonoma, California]].{{cite web|title=Airframe Dossier - Curtiss JN-4 Jenny, c/r N3223|url=http://aerialvisuals.ca/AirframeDossier.php?Serial=2470|website=Aerial Visuals|publisher=AerialVisuals.ca|accessdate=1 October 2016}}{{cite web|title=FAA REGISTRY [N3223]|url=http://registry.faa.gov/aircraftinquiry/NNum_Results.aspx?NNumbertxt=N3223|website=Federal Aviation Administration|publisher=U.S. Department of Transportation|accessdate=1 October 2016}} *10875 – JN-4C owned by John Shue in [[York, Pennsylvania]].{{cite web|title=FAA REGISTRY [N25559]|url=http://registry.faa.gov/aircraftinquiry/NNum_Results.aspx?NNumbertxt=25559|website=Federal Aviation Administration|publisher=U.S. Department of Transportation|accessdate=1 October 2016}} *MSN 65 – JN-4D on static display at the [[Denver International Airport]] in [[Denver, Colorado]].{{cite web|title=Airframe Dossier - Curtiss JN-4D Jenny, s/n SC1918 USAAC, c/n 65|url=http://aerialvisuals.ca/AirframeDossier.php?Serial=296|website=Aerial Visuals|publisher=AerialVisuals.ca|accessdate=1 October 2016}} *MSN 450 – JN-4D airworthy at [[Fagen Fighters WWII Museum]] in [[Granite Falls, Minnesota]].{{cite web|title=Curtiss JN-4 Jenny|url=http://www.fagenfighterswwiimuseum.org/aircraft/jn-4/jn-4.html|website=Fagen Fighters WWII Museum|accessdate=30 September 2016}} It was previously on display at the [[Virginia Aviation Museum]] in [[Richmond, Virginia]], on loan from Ken Hyde of [[Warrenton, Virginia]]. This airframe was built in 1918.{{cite web|title=Airframe Dossier - Curtiss JN-4D Jenny, s/n 2975 USAAS, c/n 450, c/r N2975 {2}|url=http://aerialvisuals.ca/AirframeDossier.php?Serial=23211|website=Aerial Visuals|publisher=AerialVisuals.ca|accessdate=30 September 2016}}{{cite web|title=FAA REGISTRY [N2975]|url=http://registry.faa.gov/aircraftinquiry/NNum_Results.aspx?NNumbertxt=N2975|website=Federal Aviation Administration|publisher=U.S. Department of Transportation|accessdate=30 September 2016}} *MSN 490 – JN-4 on static display at the [[National Naval Aviation Museum]] in [[Pensacola, Florida]].{{cite web|title=JN-4 "JENNY"|url=http://www.navalaviationmuseum.org/attractions/aircraft-exhibits/item/?item=jn-4_jenny|website=National Naval Aviation Museum|publisher=Naval Aviation Museum Foundation}}{{cite web|title=Airframe Dossier - Curtiss JN-4D Jenny, s/n A0995 USN, c/n 490, c/r N75234|url=http://aerialvisuals.ca/AirframeDossier.php?Serial=62575|website=Aerial Visuals|publisher=AerialVisuals.ca|accessdate=30 September 2016}} *MSN 3712 – JN-4D airworthy at the [[Flying Heritage Collection]] in [[Everett, Washington]]. This airframe was built in May 1918 and at one time served at [[March Field]] in [[Riverside, California]].{{cite web|title=CURTISS JN-4D JENNY|url=http://www.flyingheritage.com/TemplatePlane.aspx?contentId=25|website=Flying Heritage Collection|publisher=Friends of Flying Heritage|accessdate=29 September 2016}}{{cite web|title=Airframe Dossier - Curtiss JN-4D Jenny, c/n 3712, c/r N3712|url=http://aerialvisuals.ca/AirframeDossier.php?Serial=24161|website=Aerial Visuals|publisher=AerialVisuals.ca|accessdate=30 September 2016}}{{cite web|title=FAA REGISTRY [3712]|url=http://registry.faa.gov/aircraftinquiry/NNum_Results.aspx?NNumbertxt=N3712|website=Federal Aviation Administration|publisher=U.S. Department of Transportation|accessdate=30 September 2016}} *MSN 4072 – JN-4D on display at the [[Frontiers of Flight Museum]] in [[Dallas, Texas]].{{cite web|title=Curtiss JN-4D “Jenny”|url=http://www.flightmuseum.com/exhibits/aircraft-3/curtiss-jn-4d-jenny|website=Frontiers of Flight Museum|publisher=Frontiers of Flight Museum|accessdate=30 September 2016}} *MSN 4983 – JN-4D on static display at the [[Steven F. Udvar-Hazy Center]] of the [[National Air and Space Museum]] in [[Chantilly, Virginia]].{{cite web|title=Curtiss JN-4D Jenny|url=https://airandspace.si.edu/collection-objects/curtiss-jn-4d-jenny|website=Smithsonian National Air and Space Museum|publisher=National Air and Space Museum|accessdate=30 September 2016}} *MSN 8047 – JN-4D airworthy at the [[Golden Age Air Museum]] in [[Bethel, Berks County, Pennsylvania|Bethel, Pennsylvania]].{{cite web|title=1918 CURTISS JN4D "JENNY"|url=http://www.goldenageair.org/collection/1918jenny.htm|website=Golden Age Air Museum|publisher=Golden Age Air Museum|accessdate=29 September 2016}}{{cite web|title=Airframe Dossier - Curtiss JN-4D Jenny, c/r N2946|url=http://aerialvisuals.ca/AirframeDossier.php?Serial=23199|website=Aerial Visuals|publisher=AerialVisuals.ca|accessdate=30 September 2016}}{{cite web|title=FAA REGISTRY [N2946]|url=http://registry.faa.gov/aircraftinquiry/NNum_Results.aspx?NNumbertxt=N2946|website=Federal Aviation Administration|publisher=U.S. Department of Transportation}} *USMC A4160 – On static display at the [[National Museum of the Marine Corps]] in [[Triangle, Virginia]].{{cite web|title=Leatherneck Gallery|url=http://www.usmcmuseum.com/leatherneck-gallery.html|website=National Museum of the Marine Corps|publisher=National Museum of the Marine Corps|accessdate=30 September 2016}}{{cite web|title=Airframe Dossier - Curtiss JN-4HG Jenny, s/n A4160 USMC|url=http://aerialvisuals.ca/AirframeDossier.php?Serial=163458|website=Aerial Visuals|publisher=AerialVisuals.ca|accessdate=30 September 2016}} *USASC 34094 – JN-4D airworthy at the [[Owls Head Transportation Museum]] in [[Owls Head, Maine]]. This airframe was built in 1917 by the St. Louis Airplane Company.{{cite web|title=1917 Curtiss JN-4D Jenny (Original)|url=http://owlshead.org/collections/detail/1917-curtiss-jn-4d-jenny-original|website=Owls Head Transportation Museum, Maine|publisher=Owls Head Transportation Museum|accessdate=29 September 2016}}{{cite web|title=FAA REGISTRY [N2086]|url=http://registry.faa.gov/aircraftinquiry/NNum_Results.aspx?NNumbertxt=2086|website=Federal Aviation Administration|publisher=U.S. Department of Transportation|accessdate=30 September 2016}} *USASC 34135 – JN-4D airworthy at the [[Military Aviation Museum]] in [[Virginia Beach, Virginia]].{{cite web|title=WWI - Aircraft|url=http://www.militaryaviationmuseum.org/ww1-aircraft.html|website=Military Aviation Museum|publisher=Military Aviation Museum|accessdate=29 September 2016}}{{cite web|title=Airframe Dossier - Curtiss JN-4D Jenny, c/r N6898C|url=http://aerialvisuals.ca/AirframeDossier.php?Serial=30827|website=Aerial Visuals|publisher=AerialVisuals.ca|accessdate=30 September 2016}}{{cite web|title=FAA REGISTRY [N6898C]|url=http://registry.faa.gov/aircraftinquiry/NNum_Results.aspx?NNumbertxt=N6898C|website=Federal Aviation Administration|publisher=U.S. Department of Transportation|accessdate=30 September 2016}} *USASC 38428 – JN-4D on static display at the [[The Henry Ford]] in [[Dearborn, Michigan]].{{cite web|title=1917 Curtiss JN-4D "Canuck" Biplane|url=http://www.thehenryford.org/collections-and-research/digital-collections/artifact/265249|website=The Henry Ford|publisher=The Henry Ford|accessdate=1 October 2016}}{{cite web|title=Airframe Dossier - Curtiss JN-4C Jenny, s/n 38428|url=http://aerialvisuals.ca/AirframeDossier.php?Serial=75862|website=Aerial Visuals|publisher=AerialVisuals.ca|accessdate=1 October 2016}} *USASC 39158 – JN-4C on static display at the [[Canada Aviation and Space Museum]] in [[Ottawa, Ontario]]. It is painted with the registration number C227.{{cite web|title=CURTISS JN-4 “CANUCK”|url=http://casmuseum.techno-science.ca/en/collection-research/artifact-curtiss-jn-4-canuck.php|website=Canada Aviation and Space Museum|publisher=Canada Science and Technology Museums Corporation|accessdate=29 September 2016}} The airframe was acquired in 1962 and restoration was completed in May 1964.{{cite web|title=CURTISS JN-4 “CANUCK”|url=http://casmuseum.techno-science.ca/en/collection-research/research-curtiss-jn-4-canuck.php|website=Canada Aviation and Space Museum|publisher=Canada Science and Technology Museums Corporation|accessdate=29 September 2016}} *Replica – JN-4C airworthy at the [[Eagle's Mere Air Museum]] in [[Eagles Mere, Pennsylvania]].{{cite web|title=1917 Curtiss Jenny JN4|url=http://www.eaglesmereairmuseum.org/jenny.shtml|website=Eagles Mere Air Museum|publisher=Eagles Mere Air Museum|accessdate=29 September 2016|date=30 August 2014}}{{cite web|title=FAA REGISTRY [N11917]|url=http://registry.faa.gov/aircraftinquiry/NNum_Results.aspx?NNumbertxt=N11917|website=Federal Aviation Administration|publisher=U.S. Department of Transportation|accessdate=1 October 2016}} It was formerly owned by Skeeter Carlson of [[Spokane, Washington]] and is painted as C1122.{{cite web|title=Airframe Dossier - Curtiss JN-4C Jenny (replica), c/n Replica, c/r N11917|url=http://aerialvisuals.ca/AirframeDossier.php?Serial=20384|website=Aerial Visuals|publisher=AerialVisuals.ca|accessdate=1 October 2016}} *Replica – On display at the [[Combat Air Museum]] in [[Topeka, Kansas]].{{cite web|title=Curtiss JN-4D-2 Jenny Replica|url=http://www.combatairmuseum.org/aircraft/curtissjenny.htm|website=Combat Air Museum|publisher=Combat Air Museum|accessdate=30 September 2016}} *Reproduction – JN-4D on display at the [[Museum of Flight]] in [[Seattle, Washington]]. The airframe was built up from parts.{{cite web|title=Curtiss JN-4D Jenny Reproduction|url=http://www.museumofflight.org/aircraft/curtiss-jn-4d-jenny-reproduction|website=The Museum Of Green, Kentucky]].{{cite web|title=About FOJ|url=http://www.friendsofjenny.org/about-foj.html|website=Friends of Jenny|publisher=Friends of Jenny|accessdate=1 October 2016}} *Unknown ID – JN-4 on static display at the [[Cradle of Aviation Museum]] in [[Garden City, New York]]. This airframe is the aircraft owned by Charles Lindbergh in which he barnstormed long before his transatlantic flight. Lindbergh purchased this aircraft in Americus, Georgia, for $500 in May 1923, and sold it to his flying student in Iowa the following October. It was restored by the late George Dade in the 1970s and is on loan from the Long Island Early Fliers Club.{{cite web|title=Curtiss JN-4 "Jenny"|url=http://www.cradleofaviation.org/history/permanent_exhibits/world_war_i/curtiss_jn-4_jenny.html|website=Cradle of Aviation Museum and Education Center|publisher=Cradle of Aviation Museum|accessdate=29 September 2016}} *Unknown ID – JN-4 on static display in unskinned condition at the Cradle of Aviation Museum in Garden City, New York.{{citation needed|date=September 2016}} *Unknown ID – JN-4D on display at the [[Fantasy of Flight]] in [[Polk City, Florida]].{{cite web|title=1918 Curtiss JN-4D 'Jenny'|url=http://century-aviation.com/essential_grid/1918-curtiss-jn-4d-jenny|website=Century Aviation|publisher=Century Aviation|accessdate=30 September 2016}} *Unknown ID – JN-4D on static display at the [[Hill Aerospace Museum]] in [[Roy, Utah]].{{cite web|title=Curtiss JN-4D "Jenny"|url=http://www.hill.af.mil/About-Us/Fact-Sheets/Display/Article/397321/curtiss-jn-4d-jenny|website=Hill Air Force Base|accessdate=30 September 2016|date=24 September 2007}} *Unknown ID – JN-4D on static display in unskinned condition at the [[Yanks Air Museum]] in [[Chino, California]].{{cite web|title=Curtiss 1C Jenny (JN-4D)|url=http://yanksair.com/Products/30/105/Curtiss-1C-Jenny-JN-4D-1|website=Yanks Air Museum|publisher=Yanks Air Museum|accessdate=30 September 2016}}{{cite web|title=Airframe Dossier - Curtiss JN-4D Jenny, c/r N1563|url=http://aerialvisuals.ca/AirframeDossier.php?Serial=21201|website=Aerial Visuals|publisher=AerialVisuals.ca|accessdate=1 October 2016}} *Unknown ID – JN-4D on display at the Yanks Air Museum in Chino, California.{{cite web|title=Airframe Dossier - Curtiss JNS Jenny, c/n A-6, c/r N1104|url=http://aerialvisuals.ca/AirframeDossier.php?Serial=93194|website=Aerial Visuals|publisher=AerialVisuals.ca|accessdate=1 October 2016}} *Unknown ID – JN-4D on static display at the [[Glenn H. Curtiss Museum|accessdate=30 September 2016}} *Unknown ID – JN-4H airworthy at the [[Old Rhinebeck Aerodrome]] in [[Red Hook, New York]]. It is painted as a US Navy Model 1E, BuNo A6226 and is powered by a [[Hispano-Suiza 8]] engine.{{cite web|title=Curtiss JN-4H Jenny|url=http://oldrhinebeck.org/curtiss-jn-4h-jenny|website=Cole Palen's Old Rhinebeck Aerodrome|publisher=Old Rhinebeck Aerodrome|accessdate=29 September 2016}} ==Specifications (JN-4D)== [[File:Curtiss JN-4B Jenny.svg|right|thumb|Curtiss JN-4B]] {{aircraft specifications |plane or copter?=plane |jet or prop?= prop |ref=''The Encyclopedia of World Aircraft''Donald 1997, p. 280. |crew=two |capacity= |length main= 27 ft 4 in |length alt= 8.33 m |span main= 43 ft 7¾ in |span alt= 13.3 m |height main= 9 ft 10½ in |height alt= 3.01 m |area main= 352 ft2 |area alt= 32.7 m2 |airfoil= |empty weight main= 1,390 lb |empty weight alt= 630 kg |loaded weight main= |loaded weight alt= |useful load main= |useful load alt= |max takeoff weight main= 1,920 lb |max takeoff weight alt= 871 kg |more general= |engine (prop)= [[Curtiss OX-5]] |type of prop= [[V8 engine|V8]] piston |number of props=1 |power main= 90 hp |power alt= 67 kW |power original= |max speed main= 75 mph |max speed alt= 65 kn, 121 km/h |cruise speed main= 60 mph |cruise speed alt= 52 kn, 97 km/h |never exceed speed main= |never exceed speed alt= |stall speed main= |stall speed alt= |endurance=2h |ceiling main= 6,500 ft |ceiling alt= 2,000 m |climb rate main= |climb rate alt= |loading main= |loading alt= |thrust/weight= |power/mass main= |power/mass alt= |more performance= |armament= |avionics= }} ==In popular culture== ===The "Inverted Jenny" stamp=== [[File:"Inverted Jenny" C-3a (P57).jpg|thumb|left|"Inverted Jenny" (C-3a P57)]] The "[[Inverted Jenny]]" (C-3a) is a 24-cent 1918 US Air Mail [[postage stamp]] printing error in which the blue central [[Vignette (philately)|vignette]] of US Army Curtiss JN-4HM #38262, the nation's [[Airmails of the United States#U.S. Government flown Air Mail|first mailplane]], appeared as "inverted" on a single sheet of 100 stamps owing to an inadvertent error made by the operator of a hand-rolled spider press by printing the blue vignette impressions upside down after the red frames had previously been printed on the sheet.The 1918 24¢ Inverted “Jenny” (Siegel Auction catalogue, Sale 1010A, June 18, 2011), p. 8 As the Jenny vignette was only inverted on one sheet, this stamp represents the rarest and most valuable known [[United States Post Office Department|USPOD]] printing error of all time. A single example (sheet position 57) sold at auction in 2007 for $977,500.00.[http://www.siegelauctions.com/2007/946a/s946a.htm "Robert A. Siegel Auction #946a."] ''SiegelAuctions.com''. ===Notable appearances in media=== In 1921, [[Lee De Forest]] made a [[short film]] ''Flying Jenny Airplane'' in his [[Phonofilm]] [[sound-on-film]] process. The film depicted a JN-4 flying, and recorded the sound of the Jenny, as well. The short documentary was the first production of the De Forest Phonofilm company.[http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0482207 "Flying Jenny Airplane" (1921).] IMDB, Retrieved: 4 September 2011. [[File:Curtiss Jenny plane in Wichita Falls, TX IMG 6857.JPG|200px|right|thumb|This 1917 Curtiss Jenny still flies on occasion. Its home base is the Call Memorial Museum in [[Wichita Falls, Texas|Wichita Falls]], [[Texas]].]] Among many later films depicting the barnstorming era when the Jennys "ruled supreme" and played a feature role, was ''[[The Spirit of St. Louis (film)|The Spirit of St. Louis]]'' (1957) and ''[[The Great Waldo Pepper]]'' (1974).Harwick and Schnepf 1989, pp. 57, 60. In ''[[The Court Martial of Billy Mitchell]]'' (1955), authentic OX-5 Jennys were showcased as United States Army Air Service training aircraft.Harwick and Schnepf 1989, p. 55. Broadcast on April 15, 1987, by [[Public Broadcasting Service|PBS]], the ''[[National Geographic Channel|National Geographic]]'' special entitled "Treasures from the Past" featured the restoration and first flight by Ken Hyde of a JN-4D that would go on to win the "Lindy Award" at the [[EAA AirVenture Oshkosh]] '87.Chase, Gene. "From Jets to Jennies: Ken Hyde's Grand Champion Curtiss JN4D." ''Sport Aviation,''Volume 36, No. 11, November 1987, p. 52. A Jenny appears in the 1963 film ''[[It's a Mad, Mad, Mad, Mad World]]''. Musician [[Al Stewart]] refers to the Jenny in his song "[[A Beach Full of Shells|The Immelman Turn]]" (2005) in which a barnstorming acrobat falls to his death from a Curtiss Jenny attempting the maneuver in a 1923 airshow. On the TV show ''[[The Unit]]'' season 4: episode 11 "Switchblade", new character Joss Morgan of Morgan Aviation Company owns a 1917 Curtis "Jenny" and cracks a piston and ends up showing up at the Unit's front fake aviation business looking for help fixing it. She meets her future husband, unit-member Sgt. 1st Class Charles "Carlito" Grey about the piston. He then gets to buy her a drink for telling her what plane the piston was from. He then trades the broken piston for a real piston from the National Air Museum through a friend for his Colt BBQ gun. She was going to show him the "[[Aerobatic maneuver|outside loop maneuver]]". ==See also== * [[Airmails of the United States]] * [[John J. Pershing]] * [[Standard J]], the Jenny's primary "competitor" for both its military contract and in civilian barnstorming aviation exhibitions * [[Early Bird Jenny]], a homebuilt kit aircraft replica of the JN-4 ==References== {{Research help|Mil}} ;Notes {{reflist|group=N}} ;Citations {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}} ;Bibliography {{refbegin}} * Angelucci, Enzo.
